JDK 1.4 actually does include a new keyword in the language called
assert.  I haven't looked into it deeply, but it looks similar in
capability to what is available in Eiffel and (via macro) C++.

I think assertion-style internal testing is a different type of
testing.  It is really checking that the current state of the system is
*within the design parameters*.  JUnit tests actually *define* the
design parameters and check that the software behaves correctly within
them.

So I think there is definite room for both external tests and integral
tests ala assertions.  
The external tests ask a question:
  "Does the software do the right thing if conditions are foo?"
and the integral tests make a statement:
  "If conditions are not foo, I cannot run."

On Tue, 2002-02-12 at 17:14, Nilesh Thali wrote:
    Someone please clarify this for me:
    
    Manuel Amago wrote:
    
    > > it struck me why not have a self assertive code
    >
    > The only solution that I can see would be to make testing (or assertion)
    > an integral part of the language (ala Eiffel).  This would mean that
    > tests (assertions) would be an integral part of a method definition.
    
        What does self-assertive mean ? JUnit, the way i understand it, tests
        my class methods with static data that i expect.
        e.g. assertTrue(40, add(20, 20));
    
        How can i put that in my code itself ? the real data is going to be
    changing.
        All i can assert within my code is that references are not null.
    
    Thanks,
    Nilesh
